facts.text: Appellant was a quondam inspector of Central Excise.
PW1, a young man in his late twenties, started a small factory in Shadara called Uma Engineering Corporation for making insulated copper cables around June 1965.
Whole process except fitting rubber insulation done in PW1's premises; semi-finished goods taken to another factory in Delhi for insulation.
Insulated cables being dutiable, Excise authorities issued gate passes for removal of even half-finished items.
Practice prevailed till shortly before offence: removal for completion of process permitted without advance duty levy; gate passes issued on this basis.
Accused insisted even removal for further processing permissible only on payment of duty, antagonising PW1 and hampering his business.
Assistant Collector per Exhibit D-1 upheld accused's stand: directed duty-paid clearance or adherence to system of bonds for later payment per r.56A.
Duty-paid finished goods could not leave premises before pro forma Ex. D-2 filled, verified by Excise inspector and signed by him.
PW1 contacted accused and was asked to pay monthly Rs.100/- as speed money.
PW1 approached Sri Waswani, Deputy Superintendent Central Excise, with little benefit.
On August 4, 1965, PW1 met accused to get verification of statement of manufactured goods for duty payment but turned back as Rs.100/- not offered.
On August 6, 1965, PW1 went to accused's office for clearance of 2 finished bundles of cables.
Accused repeated demand for money; PW1 bargained to Rs.50/-; accused signed challan for duty deposit vide Ex.P.4.
Bribe fixed to be paid next day afternoon.
Next morning, PW1 disclosed to S.P.E. officers at Kotah House vide Ex.P.5.
Deputy SP PW7 arranged trap: PW3 and PW4 as witnesses; 5 currency notes of Rs.50/- smeared with phenolphthalein; demo of chemical reaction; details in Ex.P.6.
Raiding party went to factory; accused arrived; tea served; PW1 passed tainted notes to accused who put in pockets.
Signal given; police entered; accused surrendered currency; his hands, kerchief, trouser pocket lining turned violet in sodium carbonate solution.
Special Judge convicted accused under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.
Delhi High Court affirmed guilt but reduced sentence to one year's imprisonment vide judgment dated 31st October 1969 in Criminal Appeal No.70 of 1967.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave under Art.136.
Accused's defence: No money given; PW1 placed notes on chair and pretended payment.
PW1 admitted animus against accused.
PW4 was gazetted officer; joined trap on boss's direction; house raided later by another CBI wing; present in room admitted by appellant.

legal_issues.text: Whether the conviction under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act based on trap evidence, witness testimony and chemical test is sustainable, or is the trap tainted and evidence unreliable?
Whether there was motive for bribe post Ex.D-1, as duty payment was required anyway.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trap evidence is morally murky and tainted; courts should frown upon it as participants over-anxious and victims caught unawares.
PW1 has animus; unreliable due to station in life.
PW4 not creditworthy: prior trap involvement, house searched by CBI, contradictions.
Chemical reaction explained: PW1's hands/bottle transmitted powder to accused's hands/kerchief/pocket; PW7 contaminated lining.
No motive post Ex.D-1: duty had to be paid anyway; bribe unnecessary for semi-finished cables exit.
Investigating officers suspect species; need independent corroboration.

respondent_arguments.text: Chemical test on hands, kerchief, pocket lining proves notes came from accused's possession; no alternative explanation.
Trap bona fide; PW7 senior SPE official.

court_reasoning.text: Traps not per se tainted; necessary in corruption cases due to social milieu and proof difficulties; judicial caution and corroboration required, but acceptable here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court accepted bona fides of trap and PW7; rulings require caution, not blanket rejection.

court_reasoning.text: PW1's testimony credible despite animus; nothing to brand him liar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Case not hanging on single testimony.

court_reasoning.text: PW4 credible: gazetted officer, no animus, presence admitted; prior raid irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: PW1 + PW4 sufficient to prove acceptance of money.

court_reasoning.text: PW7 and PW8 substantially correct; chemical findings underwite prosecution story.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Science aids crime detection; accused's freak explanations rejected.

court_reasoning.text: Bribes paid not only for unlawful acts but for prompt lawful acts (speed money); signatures on gate passes/pro formas carry price; motive exists for quick turnover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delay caused to extract bribe; even on duty-paid day, signature for pro forma sought bribe.

court_reasoning.text: No perversity in concurrent factual findings; Art.136 not to undo them absent miscarriage.

holdings.text: Trap evidence admissible with caution and corroboration; conviction sustainable on credible testimony and chemical test.
Speed money constitutes illegal gratification under corruption laws even for lawful prompt acts.

statutes_cited.relevance: Charge of criminal misconduct; conviction upheld

statutes_cited.name: Central Excise Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Duty payment or bonds for semi-finished goods

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Delhi High Court's affirmation of conviction under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) PC Act, and the reduced sentence of one year's imprisonment, finding no ground to overturn concurrent factual findings.

key_quotes.text: Judicial attitudes have to be discriminating, as has happened in this case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms nuanced approach to trap evidence

key_quotes.text: Bribes are paid not only to get unlawful things done but to get lawful things done promptly since time means money.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The evidence furnished by inorganic chemistry often outwits the technology of corrupt officials.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Every pass and pro forma tempts and every discretionary power induces illicit demands.
key_quotes.speaker: court
